Description: Green glazed composition (faience) scarab; on the underside are figures and Egyptian hieroglyphs framed by a line around the edge of the field: couchant sphinx facing right with prostrate enemy below, in front of which is a vertical cartouche with prenomen of Thutmosis III; above the sphinx is the epithet 'Great God, Lord of the Two Lands'; part of the field is damaged.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Turner Bequest Excavations, Amathus
Curator's comments: For other examples of scarabs from Amathus, including many with archaeological contexts, see Forgeau 1986 and Clerc 1991. Clerc et al. 1976 discusses many contextualised examples from cultic contexts in Kition. Forgeau (171-6) and Lagarce (in Clerc et al. 1976, 167-74) provide useful overviews of the use and significance of scarabs (along with other Egyptianizing amulets) on Cyprus which often differ from those found in Egyptian contexts. Bibliography: Forgeau A. 1986, 'Scarabées, scaraboïdes et cônes', in R. Laffineur et al., Amathonte III. Testimonia 3 (Paris), 135-176. Clerc G. 1991, 'Aegyptiaca', in eds V. Karageorghis et al., La nécrople d'Amathonte Tombes 110-385. V (Nicosia), 1-50. Clerc G. et al. 1976, Fouilles de Kition. II. Objets égyptiens et égyptisants (Nicosia).
Bibliographic references: Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus (p.116, Tomb 5; p.99, Fig. 147,2)
Laffineur et al. 1986 / Amathonte III. Testimonia 3. L'Orfèvrerie. Scarabées, scaraboïdes et cônes. La coupe en argent du British Museum (pp. 143-144, no. 2)
